metadata.title: Mo<ce:inf loc=post>2</ce:inf>N as a high-efficiency catalyst for transfer hydrogenation of nitrobenzene using stoichiometric hydrazine hydrate

Table 4 Elements Atomic fraction (%) ICP-OES/Elemental analysis XPS Mo 63.6 71.1 N 36.4 28.9 Mo2N as a high-efficiency catalyst for transfer hydrogenation of nitrobenzene using stoichiometric hydrazine hydrate Shicheng Luo Writing – original draft Formal analysis Investigation a Yu Long Conceptualization Methodology Writing – review & editing a ⁎ Kun Liang Software a Xun Sun Supervision b ⁎ Jiaheng Qin Validation Software a Guangxue Yang Visualization a Jiantai Ma Resources Supervision a ⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Applied Organic Chemistry (SKLAOC), Gansu Provincial Engineering Laboratory for Chemical Catalysis, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Lanzhou University, Lanzhou 730000, China State Key Laboratory of Applied Organic Chemistry (SKLAOC) Gansu Provincial Engineering Laboratory for Chemical Catalysis College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Lanzhou University Lanzhou 730000 China aState Key Laboratory of Applied Organic Chemistry (SKLAOC), Gansu Provincial Engineering Laboratory for Chemical Catalysis, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Lanzhou University, Lanzhou 730000, China b Yantai Key Laboratory of Gold Catalysis and Engineering, Shandong Applied Research Center of Gold Nanotechnology (Au-SDARC), School of Chemistry & Chemical Engineering, Yantai University, Yantai 264005, China Yantai Key Laboratory of Gold Catalysis and Engineering Shandong Applied Research Center of Gold Nanotechnology (Au-SDARC) School of Chemistry & Chemical Engineering Yantai University Yantai 264005 China bYantai Key Laboratory of Gold Catalysis and Engineering, Shandong Applied Research Center of Gold Nanotechnology (Au-SDARC), School of Chemistry & Chemical Engineering, Yantai University, Yantai 264005, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. A straightforward and commonly-used approach of direct pyrolysis for the preparation of molybdenum nitride (Mo2N) is conducted via reduction of MoO3 under ammonia atmosphere. The as-synthesized Mo2N catalyst demonstrated high activity for transfer hydrogenation of nitrobenzene, giving a 99% aniline yield at near-room temperature of 30 °C within only 50 min. More significantly, the amount of the hydrogen donor hydrazine monohydrate (N2H4 ·H2O) can be limited to stoichiometric molar ratio (-NO2: N2H4 ·H2O = 1: 1.5), preventing the possible generation of hazardous NH3, which is seldom reported in previous protocols. Through various characterizations and control experiments, conclusively, the remarkable catalytic performance of Mo2N catalyst should be credited to the large quantity of Lewis-acidic Mo sites. This research might provide a practical approach to aromatic amines production. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Nitrobenzene Molybdenum nitride N2H4·H2O Stoichiometric synthesis Lewis-acidic sites Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Arylamines are crucial raw materials in the field of pigments, farm chemicals and pharmaceuticals, meanwhile low-cost and eco-friendly procedures for aniline synthesis have been studied all the time [1–4]. In the past decades, the chemical reduction of aniline principally depended on sodium disulfides, Fe or Zn in acidic surroundings [5]. Traditional thermo-catalysis required high pressure of H2 as reducing agent. These protocols suffered from harsh conditions and poor selectivity, bringing about safety issues and financial loss. Thus far, some alternatives such as N2H4 [6,7], NaBH4 [8,9] and HCOOH [10,11] are reported as the typical H donors for various transfer hydrogenation reactions heterogeneously, and the conversion of reactants have also achieved high level (an important requirement for a technical catalyst [12]). N2H4 ·H2O (hydrazine hydrate), the hydrated form of N2H4, is preferable for its lower toxicity. When adopting N2H4 ·H2O as hydrogen donor for title reaction, the byproducts are N2 and H2O in theory [13]. However, in the reported protocols of nitroarenes transfer hydrogenation, excess N2H4 ·H2O is always adopted rather than stoichiometric molar ratio (-NO2: N2H4 ·H2O = 1: 1.5). In this regard, some studies demonstrated that N2H4 molecules turned to be decomposed to hazardous NH3 when using excess N2H4 ·H2O as reducing agent for transfer hydrogenation of nitroarenes, leading to the wasting of active H species [14–16]. Hence, more effective and stable catalytic systems are required to realize stoichiometric transfer hydrogenation reaction. As is known to all, transition metal compounds are kinds of well-established and widely-applied catalytic materials for a large variety of redox reactions [17–20]. Therein, due to the unique platinum-like electronic structures, Mo2N has exhibited attractive reuslts [21–23]. According to Xie and co-workers, the Mo atoms are closely packed on the surface of transition metal nitrides (TMNs), and the Mo-N coordination structures turn to be assembled on the electron-deficient surface, which contribute to the generation of Lewis acid sites [24]. In our previous research, we have developed a Mo4O4N3 catalyst and attributed the catalytic activity to the unsaturated Mo-N sites [6]. The low valence-state Lewis acidic Mo sites can promote the activation of NH bonds in N2H4 ·H2O at low temperature, releasing active H species. On this basis, we prepared a γ-Mo2N catalyst via one-step pyrolysis, which delivered superior performance in the title reaction. Compared to the weight percentage (wt%) of Mo4O4N3 catalyst, we reduced that of γ-Mo2N to 10% and maintained other reaction conditions, gaining nearly the same catalytic activity. In addition, the reaction with stoichiometric N2H4 ·H2O was also achieved. The results from characterizations and activity tests revealed that the high efficiency can be ascribed to the high-density low-valence Mo sites on the surface of γ-Mo2N catalyst. The stoichiometric reaction allows a high-efficient and green catalytic protocol to arylamines production. 2 Materials and methods The materials and methods can be found in the Supporting Information. This also includes gas-chromatograms, mass spectra and an scheme depicting the different reaction routes. 3 Results and discussion We first carried out a series of control tests to explore the optimal synthesis conditions. After pyrolyzing MoO3 under NH3 atmosphere, active catalysts can be produced for the title reaction, wherein 700 °C is optimal (Table 1 , entries 1–3). In detail, when MoO3 is pyrolyzed in NH3 atmosphere at 600 °C, the obtained catalyst-MoNx-600 displayed 69% aniline yield. When the pyrolysis temperature is 800 °C, the reactivity is 50%. When changing the pyrolysis time to 8 h or 2 h, the catalyst activity drops (Table 1, entries 4 and 5). The influence of NH3 flow rate is also investigated. If the gas flow rate rise up to 200 mL/min or cuts down to 20 mL/min, the obtained catalysts both gave fairly low aniline yield (Table 1, entries 6 and 7). Based on these results, the optimal pyrolysis condition is 700 °C, 5 h, and 100 mL/min NH3 flow rate. Additionally, we carried out a 10 times large-scaled experiment, and the catalyst still remains a high activity (Table 1, entry 8), suggesting an industrial perspective. The as-prepared MoNx-700 catalyst and other precursor materials were adopted for reduction of nitrobenzene with N2H4 ·H2O stoichiometrically (-NO2: N2H4 ·H2O = 1: 1.5) at room temperature (RT). As seen, MoNx-700 exhibits 97% yield of aniline at RT for 50 min (Table 2 , entry 6). In contrast, MoO3, MoO3–700 (MoO3 was heated in air) and MoO3+N2–700 (MoO3 was heated in N2) systems all gave poor catalytic activity (Table 2, entries 1–4). When MoO3 was treated in NH3 atmosphere at room temperature, the obtained catalyst also showed no reactivity (Table 2, entry 5). Noteworthily, we produced MoNx-700 catalyst that was not passivated in N2, and the aniline yield dropped sharply to 34% at the same reaction conditions (Table 2, entry 7). This result verified the necessity of the passivation step. We infer that the decrease of the catalytic activity could be due to the chemisorption effect between Lewis-basic NH3 molecules and Lewis-acidic sites on the γ-Mo2N surface, and most active sites for the cleavage of N2H4 molecules are therefore covered. For a better understanding of this outstanding behaviour of our MoNx-700 catalyst, the performance of some reported catalysts on transfer hydrogenation of nitrobenzene using N2H4 ·H2O were compared (Table 3 ). As seen, all the catalytic system ran at relatively high temperature. Moreover, the dosage of N2H4 ·H2O is all in excess. Our catalytic system has also realized stoichiometric reaction on the basis of our previous work [6], in which the amount of catalyst is larger than this work. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns are displayed in Fig. 1 to reveal the crystal information of the as-prepared samples. The diffraction peaks of MoNx-700 are distinguished at 37.2°, 43.3°, 62.9° and 75.5°, and can be attributed to the (111), (200), (220) and (311) crystal planes of γ-Mo2N respectively [29,30]. It can be concluded that the MoNx-700 catalyst is pure a γ-Mo2N phase. Otherwise, MoNx-600 catalyst shows a sharp peak at 26°, reflecting a MoO2 phase [31], which is resulting from the incomplete nitridation of MoO3. MoNx-800 catalyst exhibits δ-MoN phase [32], and the peak intensity is obviously larger than other two catalysts, indicating the better crystallinity. To the best of our knowledge, the strong crystallinity leads to unfavourable catalytic nature of the metal compound materials, since they lack vacancies for adsorption or storage of active species. According to the catalytic performance test results, MoNx-700, that is to say γ-Mo2N delivers the best catalytic activity of the MoNx-X catalysts. These results demonstrate that γ-Mo2N is the dominant and most active catalyst of the title reaction. SEM images of MoNx-X are shown in Fig. 2 , of which MoNx-600 and MoNx-700 demonstrate an interconnected porous structure [24]. The change of MoNx-800 structure is also noticed (Fig. 2c), due to agglomeration, the interconnected porous structure disappears. This phenomenon often occurred at overhigh pyrolysis temperature and may lead to the decrease of catalytic activity [33]. The HAADF-STEM and elemental mapping image of MoNx-700 suggests that Mo and N elements are uniformly distributed, and Mo owns an obvious large proportion (Figure S2d). XPS was employed to identify the elements valence state of the as-prepared catalysts. The N 1 s spectra of MoNx-600 and MoNx-700 could be ascribed to 3 peaks at 395.2 eV, 397.8 eV and 398.9 eV. These peaks belong to Mo 3p, pyridinic-N and pyrrolic-N species respectively [34]. Noteworthily, a new peak at 397.0 eV is observed in the N 1 s spectra MoNx-800. Since the binding energy is lower than pyridinic-N, the degree of unsaturation is higher, therefore it could be ascribed to the terminal bonds between Mo and N in molybdenum nitrides [35]. As shown in Fig. 3 a, 3c and 3e, all the spectra exhibit Mo 3p signal, and peak area increases with the rise of pyrolysis temperature. What's more, for the optimal MoNx-700 catalyst, pyridinic-N content is apparently the most of 3 kinds of catalysts. Pyridinic-N benefits to the catalytic activity. Hence, pyridinic-N should be the active N, that is to say the dominant Lewis-basic sites of the catalyst. Mo 3d spectra of MoNx-X catalysts are also given (Fig. 3b, 3d and 3f). As shown in Fig. 3b, four kinds of characteristic peaks of Mo3+ at 229.0 eV and 232.1 eV, Mo4+ at 229.8 eV and 232.5 eV, Mo5+ at 230.9 eV and 234.0 eV and Mo6+ at 232.9 eV and 236.0 eV can be distinguished respectively [35–37]. Importantly, new doublet peaks in Mo 3d spectra of MoNx-700 an MoNx-800 catalysts (Fig. 3d and 3f) are discovered at 228.4 eV and 231.9 eV, implying the lower valence state- species [38]. Generally speaking, the Mo2+ and Mo3+ peaks can reflect the Mo-N and Mo-Mo-N bonds, which are the Lewis-acidic sites of the catalyst [39]. These Lewis-acidic sites benefit to the catalytic activity, facilitating the release of active H species from N2H4 molecules. To illustrate the content of Mo, N or other elements of the optimal MoNx-700 catalyst, ICP-OES and elemental analysis were performed (Table 4 ). As is known, XPS analysis can reveal the surface elemental content of the materials, while ICP elemental analysis gives information of the overall element content. Wherein, heterogenous catalytic reactions mainly take place at the surface of the catalysts, hence the surface nature is important [40]. As shown, the surface Mo content of MoNx-700 is larger than the overall Mo content, suggesting a high-density of Lewis-acidic Mo sites on the surface. To further understand the acidic sites of different catalysts, ammonia-adsorbed temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) was employed (Fig. 4 ). All the as-prepared Mo-based catalysts display a broad peak from 100 to 400 °C, which represent Lewis-acidic sites [41]. Especially, the desorption peak area of MoNx-700 catalyst is the largest of all catalysts, suggesting having more acidic sites. Hence, the NH3 desorption peak area can reflect the activity of the catalysts. In this case, MoNx-800 has the worst catalytic activity of the three catalysts, and meanwhile the NH3 desorption peak area is the smallest. MoNx-700 exhibits the best catalytic performance for its maximum Lewis-acidic sites that is reflected from the NH3-TPD profile. These results are consistent with catalytic activity tests. Taking into account of the Lewis basicity of the N2H4, the Lewis acidic low valence state Mo sites will be in favour of adsorbing the N2H4 molecules, meanwhile the active H species are produced through electron transfer. We raised a 4-step N2H4 activation mechanism cycle (Scheme 1 ). Firstly, Lewis basic N of N2H4 molecules turn to be captured by low Lewis acidic Mo2+and Mo3+ sites. The Mo of the catalyst and N from N2H4 molecules are bonded as a Lewis pair. Subsequently, the active H species will be released as Lewis acidic H species (denoted as Hδ+) and Lewis basic H species (denoted as Hδ−). Hδ+ are trapped by the N sites, while Hδ− are captured by Mo2+ and Mo3+ sites. Then the Lewis basic N sites from intermediate diimine (HNNH) continue attacking another Lewis acidic Mo site, and similarly, Hδ+ and Hδ- species are produced and trapped by Lewis sites on the catalyst surface, generating N2 as the only by-product. Subsequently, the immobilized Hδ+ and Hδ- of γ-Mo2N catalyst can react with -NO2 and reduce it to -NH2 directly. The Mo and N active sites recover to the original status, and proceed next catalytic cycle. NH3 is a hazardous by-product of the reaction (Hδ++Hδ−+N2H4→2NH3). This is resulted from weak interaction between active H species and active sites, or excess N2H4 ·H2O [15]. Our catalytic system can control the amount of N2H4 ·H2O to stoichiometric ratio and realize high aniline yield, preventing release of NH3. Hence, our catalyst is outstanding to many other catalysts for transfer hydrogenation of nitrobenzene. In order to probe the general applicability of the γ-Mo2N catalytic system, the reactivity for a series of substituted nitroarenes were studied. As seen in Scheme 2 , the γ-Mo2N catalyst delivered excellent overall performance to the reaction, no matter the substituted groups are electron-donating or electron-withdrawing. Hence, we can conclude that the catalytic system has potential in practical applications. a General Conditions: nitroarene (1.0 mmol), N2H4 ·H2O (1.5 mmol), MoNx-700 (12 mg), EtOH (1 mL), 30 °C, 1 h, air, 1200 rpm. The conversion and selectivity were determined by GC–MS using n-hexadecane as an internal standard (conversion/selectivity,%). Conclusions All in all, we developed a Mo-based MoNx-700 (γ-Mo2N) catalyst for the reaction of transfer hydrogenation of nitroarenes at room temperature. It is the second time that the stoichiometric reaction has been realized. According to the control experiments and characterizations, we attributed the excellent catalytic performance to the high-density of low-valance state Mo sites on the surface of catalyst. This work may offer a new protocol to an efficient and eco-friendly production process of amine compounds. coredata.dc:description: A straightforward and commonly-used approach of direct pyrolysis for the preparation of molybdenum nitride (Mo2N) is conducted via reduction of MoO3 under ammonia atmosphere. The as-synthesized Mo2N catalyst demonstrated high activity for transfer hydrogenation of nitrobenzene, giving a 99% aniline yield at near-room temperature of 30 °C within only 50 min. More significantly, the amount of the hydrogen donor hydrazine monohydrate (N2H4 ·H2O) can be limited to stoichiometric molar ratio (-NO2: N2H4 ·H2O = 1: 1.5), preventing the possible generation of hazardous NH3, which is seldom reported in previous protocols. Through various characterizations and control experiments, conclusively, the remarkable catalytic performance of Mo2N catalyst should be credited to the large quantity of Lewis-acidic Mo sites. This research might provide a practical approach to aromatic amines production.
coredata.dc:title: Mo2N as a high-efficiency catalyst for transfer hydrogenation of nitrobenzene using stoichiometric hydrazine hydrate
